Name_Wylie_Tibetan: Kun tu bzang po/Kun tu bzang mo
Description_English: Samantabhadra, or the Primordial Buddha in the Great Perfection tradition, existing prior to concepts of space, time, self or other. In the mind-to-mind transmission by victorious ones, the primary teacher is the union of Samantabhadra and Samantabhadrī. Radiates in the state of the natural Great Perfection without straying from the ground of awareness. Samantabhadrī is the feminine form of the primordial Buddha in the Great Perfection tradition, existing prior to concepts of space, time, self or other. Together with Samantabhadra forms the primary teacher in mind-to-mind transmission by victorious ones.

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: rgyal ba rigs lnga
Description_English: From the appearing aspect of the ground of awareness's luminous nature, the Buddhas of the five families surrounded by their maṇḍalas spontaneously arise. This marks the beginning of the saṃbhogakāya transmission of the mind-to-mind transmission by victorious ones.

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: byin brlabs mchog gi sprul pa
Description_English: A supreme emanation that manifests from the Buddhas of the Five Families, representing the blessing aspect of primordial wisdom transmission.

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: sku gzugs
sangs rgyas sras gcig
rdo rje
ye shes dam pa'i sprul pa; rDo rje 'chang
Description_English: Self-arising nirmāṇakāya emanation that spontaneously appears atop a lotus as the perfect saṃbhogakāya during the first eon called 'eon of abundant delight.' Through his own realization, teaches the natural, ineffable Great Perfection to Vajrasattva and Vajrapāṇi.
Emanated as: Buddha 1: Cheu Nangwa Dampa Samkyi Mikhyapa

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: rdo rje sems dpa'
Description_English: A saṃbhogakāya Buddha who receives the Dzogchen teachings from Sublime Wisdom Emanation (Vajradhara) through mind-to-mind transmission. In the Padmasambhava transmission, receives the Eighteen Tantras from Sublime Wisdom Emanation (Vajradhara), while in the Heart Essence of Vimalamitra lineage, receives only the Seventeen Tantras.

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: phyag na rdo rje
Description_English: A saṃbhogakāya Buddha, sometimes known as the wrathful form of Vajrasattva. Receives the Dzogchen teachings from Sublime Wisdom Emanation (Vajradhara) through mind-to-mind transmission. Like Vajrasattva, receives varying numbers of tantras depending on the transmission lineage.

Name_English: Buddha 1: Cheu Nangwa Dampa Samkyi Mikhyapa
Name_Wylie_Tibetan: khye'u snang ba dam pa bsam gyis mi khyab pa
Description_English: First of twelve Dzogchen teachers, who is a nirmāṇakāya emanation of Sublime Wisdom Emanation (Vajradhara). Located at Ganden Tsekpa. Part of the final section of the mind-to-mind transmission.

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: khye’u ’od mi ’khrugs pa
Received_Teachings_From: Buddha 1: Cheu Nangwa Dampa Samkyi Mikhyapa

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: ’jigs pa skyob pa’i yid
gzhon nu rol pa
rdo rje ’chang
gzhon nu dpa’ bo stobs ldan chen po
drang srong khros pa’i rgyal po
gser ’od dam pa
brtse bas rol pa’i blo gros
’od srung bgres po
mngon rdzogs rgyal po
shAkya thub pa
Description_English: The historical Buddha who lived as a wandering ascetic in South Asia 2500 years ago and attained enlightenment under the bodhi tree. His given name was Siddhartha and his clan name was Gautama. In Dzogchen history, received teachings from Cheu Nangwa Dampa Samkyi Mikhyapa.

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: dga' rab rdo rje
Description_English: Considered an emanation of Vajrapāṇi, born in the region of Dhanakosha in Oḍḍiyana. The 6,400,000 verses of Dzogchen tantras and the three series were primordially present in his mind. Vajrapāṇi appeared to him and granted permission to commit the tantras to writing.

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: jam dpal bshes gnyen
Description_English: Born in a brahmin family west of Bodh Gaya. Met Garab Dorjé at the charnel ground of Shitavana and remained there for 75 years mastering all teachings. Responsible for dividing the Dzogchen tantras into three categories: Mind, Space, and Pith Instruction Series.

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: dpal gyi seng ge, shrī singha
Description_English: Born in Chinese city Shocham Nakpo. Met Mañjushrimitra at Sosadvipa charnel ground. Divided the most sublime secret texts into four cycles: outer, inner, secret, and most secret unsurpassable. Achieved the luminous body and taught dharma to mamos and ḍākinīs.

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: mkha' 'gro ma
Description_English: Literally 'sky-goers' from Sanskrit root ḍī meaning to fly. Non-human feminine entities that are protectors and keepers of the Dzogchen teachings, especially important in the Padmasambhava.

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: ye shes mdo
Description_English: Born in city of Kamaru in eastern India, contemporary with Vimalamitra. Received the most unsurpassable secret cycle from Śrī Siṃha. Retrieved texts concealed by Śrī Siṃha and went to live in the charnel ground called Bhasing in India.

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: bi ma la mi tra
Description_English: Born in city of Langpo Gang in Western India, contemporary with Jñānasūtra. Received complete outer, inner, and secret cycles from Śrī Simha, and later the most unsurpassable secret cycle from Jñānasūtra. Taught five people including King Trisong Detsen and proceeded to Wu Tai Shan in China.

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: bai ro tsa na
Description_English: Born in region of Nyemo Jekar. Following King Trisong Detsen's orders, underwent 507 hardships to reach India and meet Śrī Siṃha. Received empowerments and pith instructions of sixty classes of tantra. Met Garab Dorje and received 6,400,000 verses of Dzogchen tantras.

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: spang sang rgyas mgon po
Description_English: Also known as Pang Mipam Gönpo. Only encountered dharma when very elderly, over age 85. Practiced according to oral transmissions of Vairocana, attaining siddhis and living to over 100 years old.

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: ngen lam byang chub rgyal mtshan
Description_English: Also known as Ralsumpa of Ngenlam in Uru region. Received instructions from Pang Mipam Gönpo and meditated on cliff known as Wa Senggé Drak. Reached 172 years and passed away without leaving physical remains.

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: za dam rin chen dbyig
Description_English: Student of Ngenlam from eastern Tibet. After receiving instructions, stayed at same cliff as his guru. Reached age 144 and passed away without leaving physical remains.

From Chongye in Yarlung valley. Received instructions from Zadam Rinchenyik and meditated at Wa Sengge Drak until age 117, passing away without physical remains. Transmitted teachings to multiple disciples including Yudra Nyingpo.
Students of Khugyur Salwaichok in the Vairocana lineage.

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: g.yu sgra snying po
Description_English: One of twenty-five disciples of Padmasambhava and main disciple of Vairocana. Received Heart Essence teachings from Vairocana.

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: a ro ye shes 'byung gnas
Description_English: Received Heart Essence teachings from Yudra Nyingpo.

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: se btsun
Description_English: Received Heart Essence teachings from Aro Yeshe Jungne.

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: kah dam pa bde gshegs
Description_English: Born in Belmo, Kham. Received many teachings including Dzogchen Heart Essence from Jangtön Namdak. Founded famous Katok Monastery in 1159. Authored important commentaries to the Gathering of All Intentions Sūtra.
Received Heart Essence teachings from Setsün.
10th-11th century masters and teachers of Longchen Rabjampa

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: pad+ma 'byung gnas
Description_English: Received Mind, Space, and Pith Instruction Series from Śrī Siṃha along with the Seventeen Tantras and eighteenth Tantra of the Sun. Received Padmasambhava empowerments and practiced for three years attaining vajra body. Transmitted eighteen tantras to Yeshe Tsogyel and Heart Essence to Princess Pemasel.

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: khri srong sde btsan
Description_English: 38th King of Tibet, one of the three dharma kings. Invited Shantarakshita and Padmasambhava to Tibet. Received transmissions from both Padmasambhava and Vimalamitra. Had five wives including Yeshe Tsogyel, and daughter Princess Pemasel.

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: ye shes mtsho rgyal
Description_English: Born in Chog ro Dringtsam with auspicious mark of double vajra on forehead. Offered to Padmasambhava by King Trisong Detsen. Received profound pith instructions from Padmasambhava and helped commit them to writing. Responsible for burying Padmasambhava's many Treasures.

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: myang ban ting 'dzin bzang po
Description_English: Convinced King Trisong Detsen to invite Vimalamitra to Tibet. Received full transmission from Vimalamitra, then left for China and practiced for 55 years. Hid teachings in Zha Templa with protective seals making them invisible.

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: sbas blo dros dbang phyug
Description_English: Born into the Bé clan in Pen Valley, central Tibet. Studied all pith instructions from Nyang Tingzin Zangpo. Practiced at different holy sites and achieved an immutable form of rainbow body that leaves behind no physical residue.

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: brom ston rin chen 'bar
Description_English: Born into the Drom clan in central Tibet. Received the oral lineage of the Heart Essence teachings from Bé Lodrö Wangchuk. Practiced at a cliff known as Drakar Tso and other places.

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: ldang ma lhun grub rgyal mtshan
Description_English: Received complete transmission of oral lineage from Drom Rinchen Bar. Received prophecy from deity Vajrasadhu and revealed manuscripts previously hidden by Nyang Tingzin Zangpo 100 years earlier in the temple of Zha.

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: lce btsun seng ge dbang phyug
Description_English: Received all instructions from Dangma Lhundrup Gyaltsen. Copied and re-concealed Treasure manuscripts near Takdra Spring in three places. Had visions of Vimalamitra who gave him complete Heart Essence empowerments and transmissions.

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: zhang ston bkra shis rdo rje
Description_English: Born in Lado in the region of Yardok Donang. At age 21 in 1117, revealed Treasures buried by Chetsun Wangchuk. In 1121 at age 25, met Chetsun Senggé Wangchuk and received complete transmission of Dzogchen Heart Essence teachings.

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: zhang mkhas pa nyi ma 'bum
Description_English: Son of Zhangtön Tashi Dorjé, born in 1158. Considered an emanation of Vajrapāṇi according to prophecy in the Tantra Beyond Sound. Received Heart Essence of Vimalamitra from his father and composed the commentary Eleven Words and Meanings.

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: gu ru jo 'ber
Description_English: Possible nephew to Nyima Bum. Received the whole Heart Essence transmission from Nyima Bum.

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: khrul zhig seng ge rgyab pa
Description_English: Born in town of Soge Treng in Yoru region of Tibet. Had numerous pure visions and received vision of Avalokiteśvara at age 13 telling him to practice Dzogchen Heart Essence. Received full teachings from Guru Jober.

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: sgrub chen me long mdo rje
Description_English: Born in upper part of Drak Valley. Studied with many teachers and received Dzogchen Heart Essence from Trulshik Senggé Gyabpa. Traveled to hidden lands and revealed Treasure from Drak Yongdzong known as Melong Heart Essence.

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: rig 'dzin ku ma rā dza
Description_English: Born in town Barsar Dzinkha in Yoru region. Met Melong Dorje who introduced him to the nature of mind. Served as Melong Dorjé's attendant in Bhutan and had vision of Padmasambhava. Transmitted teachings to disciples Longchenpa and Karmapa Rangjung Dorjé.

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: klong chen rab 'byams
Description_English: Born in Todtrong village in Upper Dra valley in Yoru. Met Rigzin Kumārarāja around age 25 and received Heart Essence teachings. Claimed to have had visions of ḍākinīs authenticating his identity as reincarnation of Pema Ledrelstel and Princess Pemasel.
Received_Teachings_From: Kumārarāja, Gyalsé Lekpa Gyaltsen; Rigdzin Chenpo Kumaradza; Drimé Dashar and others

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: o rgya chos rje
Description_English: 14th century student of Longchen Rabjampa

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: od gsal rang grol
Description_English: 14th century student of Longchen Rabjampa

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: sprul sku dpal 'byor rgyal mtshan
Description_English: 14th century student of Longchen Rabjampa
14th century student of Longchen Rabjampa

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: lha lcam pad+ma gsal
Description_English: Daughter of King Trisong Detsen who died at age 8 due to karmic obstacles. Revived by Padmasambhava who gave her secret name Pema Ledreltsel and transmitted Padmasambhavas to her. Prophesied to re-reveal this Treasure in future life.

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: rang 'byung rdo rje
Description_English: Third Karmapa, head of Karma Kagyü school. Born in Tsa Pugang Zhurmo. Student of Rigzin Kumararājā for Heart Essence of Vimalamitra. Received Padmasambhavas from either Tulku Lekden or Lotön Dorje Bum. Transmitted teachings to Longchenpa and Gyalwa Yungtön Dorjé Pel.

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: rgyal ba g.yung ston rdo rje dpal
Description_English: Born into Len clan in Tsongdu. Studied with many teachers including Butön Rinchen Drub and Third Karmapa. Received Mahāmudrā teachings and Padmasambhava transmission from Karmapa. Author of early transmission history of Padmasambhava.

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: me ban rin chen gling pa
Description_English: Born in Tsedrong in Loro Karpo. Treasure revealer who gave Pema Ledreltsel the prophetic guide leading to Padmasambhava. After Pema Ledreltsel revealed the Treasure, received transmission from Gyalse Legpa. Likely main teacher of Rigzin Gödemchen.

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: pad+ma las 'brel rtsal
Description_English: Reincarnation of Princess Pema Sel, reborn in Dritang. At age 23 in 1313, revealed Treasures of Padmasambhava from Danglung Tramo boulder in Dagspo. Met with inauspicious circumstances and died young.

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: prul sku legs ldan or rgyal sras legs pa
Description_English: Primary disciple of Tsultrim Dorjé/Pema Ledreltsel. Born with prophesied mole on right thigh. After receiving Heart Essence transmission, practiced diligently for twelve years. Transmitted teachings to Rinchen Lingpa, Jadralwa Zöpa, and Karmapa Rangjung Dorjé.

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: rig 'dzin rgod ldem
Description_English: Born in Nyenyul. In 1366 unearthed first of Northern Treasures in form of seven paper scrolls and four volumes of Samantabhadra's Unimpeded Realization. His Treasure includes 40-60% of original core of Padmasambhava. Credited with unearthing keys to hidden lands.

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: bya bral ba bzod pa
Description_English: Born in place called Gong. Author of main transmission histories of Padmasambhava. Received transmissions from Longchenpa, Rinchen Lingpa, and three separate transmissions from Tulku Legden.
Received_Teachings_From: Longchen Rabjampa; Meban Rinchen Lingpa; Tulku Legden/Gyalse Legpa

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: jam dbyangs mkhyen brtse'i dbang po
Description_English: Great Rime master
Received_Teachings_From: Longchen Rabjampa; Paltrul Orgyen Jigmé Chokyi Wangpo; Jetsunma Trinle Chodron

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: khyung sprul pad+ma dbang chen
Description_English: Student of Jamgön Kongtrul
Received_Teachings_From: Jamgön Kongtrul Yönten Gyatso Lodrö Tayé; Jamgön Kongtrul Yönten Gyatso Lodrö Tayé

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: rtogs ldan shAkya shrI
Received_Teachings_From: Jamgön Kongtrul Yönten Gyatso Lodrö Tayé

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: slob dpon rin po che bsod nams bzang po

Name_English: Ritrul Rigdzin Chögyal a.k.a. Drubwang Adzin Rinpoche
Name_Wylie_Tibetan: ri sprul ring 'dzin chos rgyal a.k.a. Grub dbang a 'dzin rin po che)
nam mkha' dri med rin po che
Received_Teachings_From: Ritrul Rigdzin Chögyal a.k.a. Drubwang Adzin Rinpoche

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: mi pham 'jam mgon rnam rgyal rgya mtsho
mkhan chen jam dpal bde ba'i nyi ma
zhe chen rgyal tshab 'gyur med padma rnam rgyal
Description_English: Fourth Zhechen Gyaltsap, student of Jamyang Khyentse Wangpo, Mipham Rinpoche, and Jamgön Kongtrul
Received_Teachings_From: Jamyang Khyentsé Wangpo; Mipam Jamyang Namgyal Gyatso; Jamgön Kongtrul Yönten Gyatso Lodrö Tayé; Jamyang Khyentsé Wangpo; Mipham Rinpoche; Jamgön Kongtrul Yönten Gyatso Lodrö Tayé

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: rgya khob sprul sku kun bzang
Received_Teachings_From: Jamyang Khyentsé Wangpo; Jamgön Kongtrul Yönten Gyatso Lodrö Tayé

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: rdza phu khung 'gyur med nges don dbang po
Description_English: Student of Jamyang Khyentse Wangpo
Received_Teachings_From: Jamyang Khyentsé Wangpo; Jamyang Khyentsé Wangpo

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: bdud 'joms 'jigs bral ye shes rdo rje
Description_English: Great master, student of Jedrung Trinlé Jampa Jungné and Dza Pukhung Gyurmé Ngedön Wangpo
Received_Teachings_From: Jedrung Trinlé Jampa Jungné; Dza Pukhung Gyurmé Ngedön Wangpo

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: smin gling khri chen kun bzang dbang rgyal
Description_English: Contemporary master
Received_Teachings_From: Dudjom Rinpoche Jigdral Yeshe Dorjé; Jamyang Khyentse Chökyi Lodrö; Jamyang Khyentse Chökyi Lodrö

Name_English: Dudjom Yangsi a.k.a. Dudjom Sangye Pema Shepa
Name_Wylie_Tibetan: bdud 'joms yang srid a.k.a. bdud 'joms sangs rgyas padma bzhad pa
Description_English: Contemporary reincarnation
Received_Teachings_From: Dudjom Rinpoche Jigdral Yeshe Dorjé; Chatral Rinpoché Sanjé Dorjé

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: gter chen o rgyan mchog gyur gling pa
Description_English: Treasure revealer, student of Jamyang Khyentse Wangpo
Received_Teachings_From: Jamyang Khyentsé Wangpo; Jamyang Khyentsé Wangpo

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: sprul sku o rgyan rin po che
Description_English: Contemporary master, familial relationship with Terchen Orgyen Chokgyur Lingpa

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: gnas brtan mchog gling
Received_Teachings_From: Terchen Orgyen Chokgyur Lingpa; Jamyang Khyentse Chökyi Lodrö

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: o rgyan stobs rgyal rin po che
Description_English: Contemporary master
Received_Teachings_From: Öpame Thekchok Dorje; Neten Chokling; Jamyang Khyentse Chökyi Lodrö; Jamyang Khyentse Chökyi Lodrö
Notes: Orgyen Tobgyal has familial relationship w ppl, probably not all. so you need to sus out whos fam and who isnt. we def need to modify the csv to accomodate fam vs normal teaching relationships.

Description_English: Contemporary master

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: thub bstan chos kyi rdo rje

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: dge rtse'i 'jigs med ngo mtshar bstan 'dzin
Description_English: He was a direct student of Jigmé Lingpa (and one of the Four Jikmés) as well as a student of the Third Dzogchen Rinpoche. He taught luminaries such as Gyalsé Shenpen Tayé and Patrul Rinpoche. He founded Kilung Monastery in 1790. (Rigpa)

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: jigs med kun grol
Description_English: He was a direct student of Jigmé Lingpa and one of the Four Jigmés. He was born in Wangdar Lung, Bhutan. In his youth he trained in the Drukpa Kagyü lineage but, while serving as the manager for his monastery, he witnessed the killing of animals for meat and deep compassion arose within him. Thereupon he left his monastery and went to Tibet, where he received a complete monastic education at the renowned Mindroling Monastery. When he heard that the great master Jigmé Lingpa was residing at Samye, he decided to go there. He was accepted as a personal disciple by Jigmé Lingpa, from whom he received all the precious lineage transmissions. Practising under Jigmé Lingpa’s guidance, he obtained accomplishment and was recognized as one of the latter’s four supreme disciples. Following his master’s orders, he returned to Thawa Drak in Bumtang, Bhutan, where he established his residence. He then went on to Dungsam and built a monastery called Yongleg Gon. He was especially powerful in the practice of Vajrakilaya.

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: kaH thog rgyal sras bsod nams lde'u btsan
Img_Subtext: Source: Treasury of Lives via HAR
Description_English: 17th-18th century master. He was the son of Longsal Nyingpo and the immediate reincarnation of Rigdzin Düddul Dorje. He and his father were renowned nyingma masters, and both played a critical role in re-strengthening the Katok Monastery lineage and its monastery. Katok Gyalse Sönam Deutsen had a son called Japhur Lama, who travelled to and settled in Pemakö, and whose next incarnation was Khengen Tulku, Dudjom Rinpoche's father. Drimé Shyingkyong Gönpo (dri med zhing skyong mgon po) has been recognized as a reincarnation of Katok Gyalse Sönam Deutsen.

Description_English: An extraordinary master who was the teacher of some of the greatest lamas of the last century, such as Jamyang Khyentse Wangpo, Do Khyentse, Patrul Rinpoche and Mipham Rinpoche. He reached the state of realization of Dzogpachenpo called chö nyi zé sa, ‘the wearing out of phenomenal reality’ (the fourth vision of tögal practice), and had completely transcended all worldly concerns and conventional norms. (From Rigpa)
Received_Teachings_From: Du Khyentsé Yeshé Dorjé; 1st Dodrupchen, Jigmé Trinlé Özer

Name_English: Gemang Gyalse Rigpai Dorjé (Gyalse Zhenpen Tayé Özer)
Name_Wylie_Tibetan: rgyal sras gzhan phan mtha' yas
Description_English: Gyalsé Shenpen Tayé was an incarnation of Minling Terchen Gyurmé Dorjé (1646-1714). He followed many great Sarma and Nyingma masters of the Rimé movement, especially the first Dodrupchen Rinpoche Changchup Dorjé (aka Jikmé Trinlé Özer) (1745-1821), Jikmé Gyalwé Nyugu (1765-1843), the Fourth Dzogchen Rinpoche Mingyur Namkhé Dorjé (1793–1870), Sengtruk Pema Tashi, Minling Trichen[3] and Minling Khen Rinpoche. His collected works include a commentary on the Guhyagarbha Tantra entitled The Heart Essence of Samantabhadra (ཀུན་བཟང་ཐུགས་ཀྱི་ཏི་ཀ་, kun bzang thugs kyi ti ka). His personal students included Jikmé Gyalwé Nyugu and all three incarnations of Jikmé Lingpa—Patrul Rinpoche, Do Khyentse Yeshe Dorje and Jamyang Khyentse Wangpo—as well as Shechen Öntrul Thutob Namgyal, Minling Trichen Sangye Kunga and the great Dzogchen Khenpo Pema Dorje. (Rigpa Wiki)
Received_Teachings_From: Barchung Lama Tashi Gyatso; 1st Dodrupchen, Jigmé Trinlé Özer

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: mkhan chen yon tan rgya mtsho
Description_English: 19th-20th century student of Paltrul Rinpoche and Orgyen Tendzin Norbu. He belonged to Gemang Monastery, a branch of Dzogchen Monastery, and studied at Dzogchen and Shechen monasteries. He wrote a very popular two-part commentary on Rigdzin Jigmé Lingpa's Treasury of Precious Qualities, called Lamp of Moonlight and Rays of Sunlight, or simply Great Commentary (Wyl. zla ba’i ’sgron me). He also wrote an important commentary to Ngari Panchen's Ascertainment of the Three Types of Vows, the Awareness Holders’ Entrance. Among his students were Changma Khenchen Thubten Chöpel (the teacher of Dilgo Khyentse Rinpoche and Khenpo Jikmé Phuntsok) and Khenchen Tsewang Rigdzin of Washul Mewa (who attained the rainbow body). (Rigpa Wiki).

Received_Teachings_From: Nyoshul Lungtok Tenpai Nyima Gyaltsen Palzangpo

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: lcang ma mkhan chen thub bstan chos 'phel
Description_English: Student of Khenchen Yönten Gyatso. He was renowned for his great scholarship, especially in relation to the Guhyagarbha Tantra, his contribution to the flourishing of the monastic tradition, and his realization of the Dzogchen teachings. Some of his most important students were: Dilgo Khyentse Rinpoche, Khenpo Jikmé Phuntsok, Gonpo Tseten Rinpoche, Chagdud Tulku Rinpoche and the Sixth Dzogchen Rinpoche, Jikdral Changchub Dorje. (Rigpa Wiki).

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: mkhan chen tshe dbang rig 'dzin
Description_English: Student of Khenchen Yönten Gyatso, who attained rainbow body. He also studied with Lala Sönam Chödrup, Khenpo Shenga and many other great masters of his time. One of his principal disciples was his nephew Mewa Khenpo Tupten Özer. (Rigpa Wiki).

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: bod sprul mdo sngags bstan pa'i nyi ma
Description_English: Student of Khenchen Kunzang Palden Chodrak

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: me ba mkhan po thub bstan 'od zer
Description_English: 20th century student of Bötrul Do-ngak Tenpai Nyima. He was born in Mewa in Nyarong in Eastern Tibet. His father was Tsering Wangchuk and his mother was called Lhakyi. At the age of seven he entered Mewa monastery and received ordination from Khenpo Yeshe Dargye and was given the name Tupten Özer. He received teachings from his paternal uncle, Khenchen Tsewang Rigdzin, who attained the rainbow body, and from his maternal uncle, Khenpo Sonam Nyima, as well as from Khenpo Tubga of Changma hermitage, and in particular from his main teacher, Pöpa Tulku. He arrived in India in 1959, and in 1964 he took up residence in Manali, in Himachal Pradesh, in a place called Pagan. There he spent many years in retreat and taught extensively. His students include Dzogchen Rinpoche and Khenpo Könchok Mönlam. (Rigpa Wiki).

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: ra hor mkhan thub bstan rin po che
Description_English: 20th century student of Bötrul Do-ngak Tenpai Nyima. He was from Rahor, a branch of Dzogchen monastery founded by the Third Dzogchen Rinpoche in Gyalrong near Dergé. He was a student of Pöpa Tulku. He escaped from Tibet together with his former classmate Khenpo Dazer and went together with him to Sikkim via Bhutan. (Rigpa Wiki)

Img_Subtext: Source: Rigpa Wiki, courtesy of drugpa.org
Description_English: 20th century student of Khenchen Ngawang Palzangpo. He was recognized by Jamyang Khyentse Chökyi Lodrö as the thirty-sixth incarnation of the lotsawa Vairotsana. He was an important holder of the Katok lineage. His main seat, Shyichen Monastery in Golok, is one of the major branches of Katok Dorje Den Monastery in eastern Tibet. Shyichen Monastery has its own group of over twenty branch monasteries throughout the region. Bairo Rinpoche's older brother was Katok Moktsa Rinpoche. Bairo Rinpoche received the Nyingtik Yabshyi and other cycles of the secret Nyingtik teachings from Khenpo Ngawang Palzang. (Rigpa Wiki).

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: bya bral sangs rgyas rdo rje
Img_Subtext: Source: Rigpa Wiki, courtesy of Carol Shlenger
Description_English: Student of Khenchen Ngawang Palzangpo. Chatral Rinpoche also studied with some of the last century's most renowned masters, including Dudjom Rinpoche, Jamyang Khyentse Chökyi Lodrö, and the famed dakini, Sera Khandro. Rinpoche was one of the primary lineage holders of the Longchen Nyingtik, and in particular the lineage that descends through Jigme Lingpa's heart son Jikmé Gyalwé Nyugu and then on to Patrul Rinpoche. Though his main lineage is the Longchen Nyingtik, Chatral Rinpoche was also closely associated with the Dudjom Tersar lineage. He was empowered as the regent of Kyabjé Dudjom Rinpoche and passed on this lineage to this master's reincarnation, who lives primarily in central Tibet. (Rigpa Wiki).

Description_English: Student of 2nd Palyul Drupwang Pema Norbu. He was the 11th throne holder of the Palyul Lineage of the Nyingma school of Tibetan Buddhism. He was the supreme head of the Nyingmapa lineage from 1993 to 2001.
Received_Teachings_From: 2nd Palyul Drupwang Pema Norbu, Rigdzin Kunzang Shedrupa

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: jigs med phun tshogs 'byung gnas
Description_English: Student of Changma Khenchen Tupten Chöpel

Description_English: 19th-20th century student of Orgyen Tendzin Norbu. He was a teacher of Dilgo Khyentse Rinpoche and Khunu Lama Tenzin Gyaltsen.

Name_English: Zhenga Dorjé Chang Zhenpen Chökyi Nangwa

Description_English: Student of Orgyen Tendzin Norbu
Received_Teachings_From: Orgyen Tendzin Norbu; Bo Gangkar Rinpoché
Incarnation_Of: Gemang Gyalse Rigpai Dorjé (Gyalse Zhenpen Tayé Özer)

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: mchog sprul blo bzang bstan 'dzin
Description_English: 19th-20th century student of Dergé Lama Kunga Palden

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: a pang gter ston o rgyan phrin las gling pa
Img_Subtext: Source: Rigpa Wiki, courtesy of www.aming.cc
Description_English: Treasure revealer whose body could pass through solid objects and who discovered many terma teachings, and one of Dudjom Lingpa's miraculously conceived sons. (Rigpa Wiki)

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: byang chub rdo rje
Description_English: 20th century student of Apang Terchen. Born in Golok, Tibet, he also studied with Dzongter Kunzang Nyima, Jamyang Khyentse Chökyi Lodrö and Dudjom Rinpoche. He was responsible for transmitting Apang Tertön's lineage to the tertön's tulku, His Holiness Sakya Trizin. Changchub Dorje also gave Apang Tertön's Red Tara cycle to Chagdud Tulku Rinpoche. (Rigpa Wiki)

Name_English: Palpung Tai Situ Rinpoché Pema Wangchok Gyalpo
Name_Wylie_Tibetan: pad ma dbang mchog rgyal po
Description_English: Student of Zhenga Dorjé Chang. He was recognized at the age of four as the reincarnation of the previous Tai Situ by the Fifteenth Karmapa, Khakhyap Dorje, Palpung Situ Pema Wangchok Gyalpo was then enthroned at Palpung Monastery. He received ordination and teachings from Khakhyap Dorje, as well as teachings and empowerments from Jamgön Kongtrul Lodrö Thayé. Situ Rinpoche later recognized the Sixteenth Gyalwa Karmapa, Rangjung Rigpé Dorje, and performed his enthronement and ordination. He transmitted the complete teachings to him and bestowed all the initiations, explanations and empowerments. Palpung Situ Pema Wangchok Gyalpo was also one of the main teachers of the Second Jamgön Kongtrul Rinpoche, Karsé Kongtrul. At about the age of fifty he visited the great Surmang Monastery, and performed many miracles. He passed the rest of his life partly in meditation and partly giving teachings to his many disciples. At the age of 67 he passed away amidst many auspicious signs. (Rigpa Wiki)
Received_Teachings_From: Zhenga Dorjé Chang Zhenpen Chökyi Nangwa

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: khu nu bla ma bstan 'dzin rgyal mtshan
Description_English: Student of Zhenga Dorjé Chang. He was also a teacher of His Holiness the Dalai Lama, especially for the Bodhicharyavatara, for which he held Patrul Rinpoche’s lineage, having received it from one of the great khenpos at Dzogchen monastery. (Rigpa wiki)
Received_Teachings_From: Zhenga Dorjé Chang Zhenpen Chökyi Nangwa

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: rdo ring sprul sku 'jam dbyangs kun bzang lung rig chos kyi nyi ma
Description_English: 20th century student of Zhenga Dorjé Chang. He was recognized as a direct incarnation of Do Khyentse Yeshe Dorje. In 1933, he went to Bhutan and founded Nyimalung Monastery there. While back in Tibet in 1940, he roamed widely throughout Tibet, went to Lama Ling and became a direct student of Dudjom Rinpoche. (Rigpa Wiki)
Received_Teachings_From: Zhenga Dorjé Chang Zhenpen Chökyi Nangwa

Name_Wylie_Tibetan: dzi sgar kong sprul blo gros
Description_English: Student of Palpung Tai Situ. He was one of the five immediate reincarnations of Jamgön Kongtrul. Dzigar Kongtrul Lodrö Rabpel was recognized by the Fifteenth Karmapa, Khakhyap Dorje and subsequently enthroned and brought up at Palpung Monastery. There, he studied the sutras with the great Khenpo Shenga, and did a three-year retreat above Palpung, at the historic Tsadra Rinchen Drak retreat centre founded by his predecessor. At some point he left Palpung Monastery and went to Neten Monastery, which was headed at that time by the Third Neten Chokling Pema Gyurme. There, he received the Treasury of Precious Termas from, and studied with Kyungtrul Kargyam, one of the foremost disciples of Jamgön Kongtrul Lodrö Tayé. He eventually established his own monastery near Neten Monastery in a place where there was a beautiful lake and so his monastery became known as Tsokar Monastery. (Rigpa Wiki)
Received_Teachings_From: Palpung Tai Situ Rinpoché Pema Wangchok Gyalpo
Incarnation_Of: Jamgön Kongtrul Yönten Gyatso Lodrö Tayé
